Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The graphs show the distance, \(d\), traveled by two cars, A and B, over time, \(t\). Distance is measured in miles, and time is measured in hours.

Correct! Car A traveled slower because Car B was a farther distance in the same amount of time as Car A.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.8.1–4.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Car A traveled slower because Car B was a farther distance in the same amount of time as Car A. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. An empty 20-gallon water tank is filled at a constant rate for 3 minutes until it is half full. Then, it is emptied at a constant rate for 3 minutes.

Correct! Graph 3

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.8.1–4.8.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Graph 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A full 10-gallon water tank is drained for 30 seconds, until it is half full. Afterward, it gets refilled.

Correct! Graph 1

The correct answer is Graph 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. An empty 100-gallon water tank is filled in 50 minutes. Then, a dog jumps in and splashes around for 10 minutes, letting 7 gallons of water out. The tank is refilled afterward.

Correct! Graph 4

For questions 6–7, use this situation and function:
The daily cost to the manufacturing company is modeled by the function \(C(x)=7.25x+2500\), where \(C(x)\) is the total daily cost and \(x\) is the number of items manufactured.

  1. What is \(C(0)\)? Enter only integers.

Correct! 2500

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.8.1–4.8.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 2,500. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What does C(0) mean in the context of the situation?

Correct! Cost before any items are manufactured

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.8.1–4.8.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is cost before any items are manufactured. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
